ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Otosclerosis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Bilateral mixed hearing loss with significant air-bone gaps, normal tympanograms, and absent acoustic reflexes; confirmed by CT scan.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Noise-induced hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of occupational noise exposure (carpenter) and acoustic trauma (shotgun blast); high-frequency involvement.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: External otitis (Left)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Diagnosed by otologist; consistent with patient report of otalgia.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Hyperacusis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient reports pain to loud sounds and impulse noises; sensitivity increased after acoustic trauma.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To determine the degree, type, and configuration of hearing loss.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
To evaluate middle ear status given the mixed hearing loss.
To assess the stapedial reflex arc and check for retrocochlear pathology.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiometry reveals a bilateral, asymmetric mixed hearing loss (Right worse than Left) with significant air-bone gaps. Despite the conductive component, tympanograms are normal (Type A), but acoustic reflexes are absent bilaterally. This constellation of findings (mixed loss, normal tympanograms, absent reflexes) is clinically characteristic of otosclerosis, likely superimposed on noise-induced hearing loss given the history. Speech recognition is good in the right ear and fair in the left.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right: Moderately severe to severe mixed loss (250-3000 Hz), sloping to profound (4000 Hz), rising to severe (6000-8000 Hz). Left: Moderate to moderately severe mixed loss (250-1000 Hz), sloping to severe/profound (2000-4000 Hz), rising to severe (6000-8000 Hz). Significant air-bone gaps bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT: Right 78 dB HL, Left 72 dB HL. WRS: Right 95% (at 95 dB HL), Left 80% (at 105 dB HL).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes absent from 500 to 4000 Hz in both ears.

proposed_items: Ciprodex ear drops (for left external otitis)
Use of hearing protection in noise
Fit with new hearing aids with impulse sound suppression algorithm
counseling_actions: Explain the diagnosis of otosclerosis and noise-induced hearing loss
Counsel on hyperacusis and the importance of not over-protecting ears in quiet environments
Discuss the benefits of impulse noise suppression in hearing aids

escalation.rationale_short: For medical management of external otitis and evaluation/confirmation of otosclerosis.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing aid benefit and hyperacusis management.

expected_outcome: Otologist diagnosed left external otitis and prescribed Ciprodex ear drops.
Patient was fit with new hearing aids with an algorithm that suppressed impulse sounds.
Patient did well with the hearing aids.
